EXECUTIVE SUMMARY / RMP SUBMIT



CORPORATE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE APPROACHES



At this facility, Illinois-American Water Company handle chlorine for the purpose of disinfecting and treating drinking water, ammonia for the purpose of increasing the disinfection residual and sulfur dioxide for the purpose of dechlorinating waste sludge.  OSHA and EPA consider chlorine a hazardous chemical.  The hazards of chlorine, ammonia and sulfur dioxide make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in the use and handling to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is Illinois-American Water Company policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends on the manner that covered process chemicals are handled and used, combined with the safety devices inherent in the design along with operating procedures and the training of our personnel.



The emergency action plan is based upon OSHA 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans) 1910.120 (Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response) and experience obtained from community drills.



THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The maximum amount of chlorine stored at the East St. Louis facility is 130,000 pounds.

The maximum amount of ammonia stored at the East St. Louis facility is 40,000 pounds.

The maximum amount of sulfur dioxide ammonia stored at the East St. Louis facility is 40,000 pounds.

The chlorine is delivered by truck in one-ton cylinders.  Liquid chlorine is added to water by

evaporating chlorine liquid to gas, metering the gas through an injector, and then diffusing the gas into the flow stream of water at the point of application.

Anhydrous Ammonia is delivered by tanker truck. Liquid ammonia is added to water by

evaporating ammonia liquid to gas, metering the gas through an injector, and then diffusing the gas int

o the flow stream of water at the point of application.

Sulfur Dioxide is delivered by truck in one-ton cylinders.  Liquid sulfur dioxide is added to waste sludge by

evaporating chlorine liquid to gas, metering the gas through an injector, and then diffusing the gas into the flow stream of water and sludge at the point of application.



Senior Management is committed to the safe operation of our facilities and its impact on the surrounding communities.



THEORY OF OPERATION 

The East St. Louis plant chlorinators and accessories are designed to control and indicate the rate of flow of chlorine to provide a simple means setting the feed rate at any value within the range of the machine, to mix the chlorine gas with water, and to deliver the resultant solution to the point of application.



From the vacuum regulator-check unit, gas under a controlled vacuum passes through a rotameter (feed rate indicator) causing the float to indicate the rate of flow in pounds per 24 hours on a large, easily read scale. The rate of flow is controlled by the position of the variable orifice across which a constant differential at less than atmospheric pressure is maintained by the operation of the differential regulating valve.  From the differential regulating valve, gas passes to the injector where it is mixed with water.  The resultant solution is discharged to the point of application.



The function of the injector is to produce a vacuum to draw gas from the chlorinator and to mix this gas with the water flowing through the injector.  A ball check and diaphragm check are built into the injector to prevent a back flow of water into the chlorinator if the injector water supply is shut off with pressure on the injector discharge or if the injector discharge line is restricted.  Proper operation of the injector is dependent on the inlet pressure being sufficiently higher than the discharge pressure.  In the chlorinator, the differential regulating valve throttles the injector v

acuum to maintain a constant drop across the variable orifice.  Thus the flow through the orifice is entirely a function of the size of the orifice as determined by the position of the rotameter as manually, or scada set by the operator.



 3.1 THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This facility and process uses design codes and standards from the Chlorine Institute, Capitol Controls Manuals, American National Standards Institute, American Society for Testing and Materials, and applicable state codes and regulations.



 3.2 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

  We have had no accidental releases of chlorine, ammonia or sulfur dioxide in the past five years.



 3.3 THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

 The written emergency response program as mentioned in the opening paragraph is located at the facility with an ongoing training program.  Fire department inspections/tours are conducted annually, identifying on-site chemicals, storage locations, chemical hazards, special instructions and requirements. Drills at this facility are coordinated with the local fire department. Public notification will be handled through the local fire department per the emergency action plan.





 3.4 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Although there are no immediate plans for changes to improve safety at this facility. We constantly review advancement in safety and process technology for the continuing pursuit to provide a safer workplace and community.
